questions.question: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts?
A young woman presented with the following lesion on her vulva. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given image is suggestive of condyloma acuminata that shows cauliflower-like masses oftissue on and around the female anogenital region.Condyloma acuminatum is an epidermal manifestation of the human papillomavirus (HPV).HPV is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells ofthe epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. However, anogenital HPV infection is almostalways acquired through sexual contact.Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load.Option B: The image given below shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules with acharacteristic dimple at the centre. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum caused by the poxvirus.Molluscum contagiosumPearly white wart-like umbilicated papules722Option C: The image given below shows firm papules with a rough horny surface. These are seenin verruca vulgaris caused by the human papillomavirus type 2.DAILYROUNDSOption D: The image given below shows condyloma lata which is the characteristic feature ofsecondary syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum.

questions.question: 716A sexually active woman presents with cauliflower-like lesions on the vulva. The biopsy of thelesion is taken and histopathology reveals the following picture. What is the most likelycausative organism?
questions.explanation: The given image shows koilocytes, a characteristic feature of infection with human papillomavirus(HPV).Other features that can also be seen on histology are:• Perinuclear halo723• Multinucleation• Orangeophilic cytoplasm• Acanthosis• Chronic inflammatory infiltrateOption A: Henderson-Paterson bodies are seen in molluscum contagiosum, caused by poxvirus.Option C and D: Cowdry bodies are seen in herpes infection.

questions.question: Which of the following serotypes are present in the bivalent vaccine against the humanpapillomavirus?
questions.explanation: Serotypes 16 and 18 are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus (HPV).It is called Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months.Gardasil/Silgard is the quadrivalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16 and 18 and isgiven at 0, 2 and 6 months.Gardasil 9 is the nonavalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and58. In 2020 it has received an expanded indication which now includes the prevention oforopharyngeal and head and neck cancers.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a treatment option for a patient with genital warts?
questions.explanation: Genital warts are treated by a local application of 25% trichloracetic acid + 5% fluorouracil.Treatment of genital warts includes the local application of:••Podophyllin 25% in alcohol/podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin daily for 4 days (or)25% trichloracetic acid +5% fluorouracil daily for 4 daysIf this fails, the following treatment is given:•• Interferon ointment/cream or intralesional interferon injection.•Imiquimod cream thrice a week for 4 monthsIf medical treatment fails then cryosurgery, diathermy or laser removal is done.

questions.question: A sexually active woman who presented with an ulcer over the vulva was diagnosed withprimary syphilis. What is the characteristic feature associated with this condition?

options.A: Non suppurative, tender, and enlarged nodes
options.B: Firm, shotty, and painless nodes that do not suppurate
options.C: Painful, tender, and matted nodes forming an abscess
options.D: Painful, inflamed, necrotic nodes developing a chronic sinus

questions.explanation: The characteristic feature associated with primary syphilis is firm, shotty, painless nodes that donot suppurate.Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the motile spirochete, Treponema pallidum.In primary syphilis, the classical lesion i.e., chancre appears within 9-90 days from the firstexposure.724The macular lesion becomes papular and then ulcerates. The ulcer(s) is painless and firm, with apunched out base and rolled edges. If left unattended, these heal within 3-9 weeks. It isaccompanied by painless inguinal discrete lymphadenopathy.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman known to have syphilis presented with the following lesions over thevulva. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.explanation: The given image shows condyloma lata, a classic finding of secondary syphilis.Multiple moist well-demarcated papules and plaques are seen in condyloma lata. They are highlycontagious, exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate and are commonly seen on the vulva,perianal area and upper thighs.

questions.question: 718A sexually active patient was diagnosed with lymphogranuloma venereum. What is thecausative organism for this condition?
questions.explanation: The causative agent for lymphogranuloma venereum is Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypesL1/L2/L3). Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted disease that causesgenital ulcers.It has the following three stages of infection:Chlamydia trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasitethat appears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. The gram stain of the cervical smear wouldshow leucocytes but no organisms. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture isused to isolate the organism.The slide given below is an iodine-stained smear prepared from the patient's endocervical sample.It shows inclusion bodies characteristic of Chlamydia trachomatis.Stage of LGVPrimary stageSecondary stageLate stageCharacteristic featuresPainless genital ulcerPapulesLymphangitisPainful unilateral/bilateral lymphadenopathy BuboesGroove signStricture formation Fibrosis and fistulae of the anogenital region725

questions.question: A 26-year-old sexually active man comes to the STD clinic with a painful genital ulcer. Onexamination, the ulcer and the right inguinal lymph nodes were tender. What is the causativeorganism?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi which is agram-negative anaerobe.Chancroid is symptomatic in men. Both ulcer and lymphadenopathy arepainful. Lymphadenopathy in chancroid is either unilateral or bilateral. Chancroid is generallyasymptomatic in women but sometimes presents as painful lymphadenopathy.The image below shows a chancroid ulcer with purulent and haemorrhagic discharge. It hasa non-indurated, erythematous base.726

questions.question: A sexually active man presents with complaints of painful swelling over the inguinal region.He also gives a history of a painless genital ulcer that resolved spontaneously. Onexamination, groove sign is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The pathognomic groove sign of Greenblatt is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1, L2, L3).This image shows groove sign which is seen in of the cases in the secondary stage of LGV. Itrefers to the depression between the enlarged femoral and inguinal lymph nodes on either side ofthe inguinal ligament.Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted disease that causes genital ulcers. Ithas the following three stages of infection:727Stage of LGVCharacteristic featuresPrimary stagePainless genital ulcerPapulesLymphangitisSecondary stageLate stagePainful unilateral/bilateral lymphadenopathyBuboesGroove signStricture formation Fibrosis and fistulae of the anogenital region

questions.question: A 20-year-old female sex worker presents with complaints of constipation and blood in stoolsfor 3 months. On DRE, a circumferential constriction is felt beyond which the finger cannotbe advanced. Which of the following is a probable cause for this complication?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rectal stricture which is a complicationof lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1/L2/L3).Rectal involvement is commonly seen in women as the primary disease often goes unnoticed anduntreated. Anorectal involvement causes proctocolitis and causes rectal strictures. This occurs dueto the contiguous spread of the primary infection from the perirectal nodes leading to scar tissueformation.The complications of lymphogranuloma venereum include:• Rectal stricture formation may lead to:• Intestinal obstruction.• Rectovaginal fistulae• Proctitis•• Vulvar cancer.

questions.question: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale?
questions.explanation: The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacteriumgranulomatis. It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causingchronic ulcerative infection of the vulva.It is highly contagious and transmitted through repeated sexual or non-sexual contact. Theincubation period is 1-12 weeks.Clinical features:It begins as a painless nodule which later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers thattend to coalesce; the vulva is progressively destroyed, and minimal adenopathy may occur.Diagnosis:Microscopic examination of smears from the lesion/ biopsy specimens reveals pathognomonicintracytoplasmic Donovan bodies and clusters of bacteria with a bipolar (safety pin) appearance.728Blue-black stained organisms are seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear cells.Management:Azithromycin 1 g orally once per week or 500 mg daily for at least 3 weeks and until all lesionshave completely healed.The given image below shows the donovanosis in a female patient with a beefy red ulcer:

questions.question: A 19-year-old girl presented with multiple beefy-red ulcers over the labia. Microscopicexamination of smear from the lesion showed intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies andgram-negative bacteria having a safety pin appearance. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by agram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis.Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy redpainless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected,they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resemblingkeloids.The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged. New lesions can appear alongthe lymphatic drainage channels.The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance ofthe hypervascular intravaginal tissues.729The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It alsoshows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.730
